articles.headline: What Happens to the Markets if Donald Trump Wins?
articles.snippet: A Trump victory probably would lead to an immediate market sell-off, the direction in the days and weeks that follow is not clear.
articles.abstract: A Trump victory probably would lead to an immediate market sell-off, the direction in the days and weeks that follow is not clear.
articles.lead_paragraph: Assume, for a moment, that Donald J. Trump wins the presidency.

articles.headline: Donald Trump Used Legally Dubious Method to Avoid Paying Taxes
articles.snippet: Thanks to a maneuver later outlawed by Congress, Mr. Trump potentially escaped paying tens of millions of dollars in federal personal income taxes.
articles.abstract: Thanks to a maneuver later outlawed by Congress, Mr. Trump potentially escaped paying tens of millions of dollars in federal personal income taxes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump proudly acknowledges he did not pay a dime in federal income taxes for years on end. He insists he merely exploited tax loopholes legally available to any billionaire — loopholes he says Hillary Clinton failed to close during her years in the United States Senate. “Why didn’t she ever try to change those laws so I couldn’t use them?” Mr. Trump asked during a campaign rally last month.
articles.byline: By David Barstow, Mike McIntire, Patricia Cohen, Susanne Craig and Russ Buettner

articles.headline: James Comey Role Recalls Hoover’s F.B.I., Fairly or Not
articles.snippet: Though Mr. Comey acted publicly, while J. Edgar Hoover maneuvered in secret, Hoover was the last F.B.I. director to be accused of trying to influence a presidential election.
articles.abstract: Though Mr. Comey acted publicly, while J. Edgar Hoover maneuvered in secret, Hoover was the last F.B.I. director to be accused of trying to influence a presidential election.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Since President Obama named James B. Comey director of the F.B.I. in 2013, the 6-foot-8 former prosecutor has spoken often of dark chapters in the bureau’s history, notably J. Edgar Hoover’s order to wiretap the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and use the tapes to try to drive the civil rights leader to suicide.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane and Sharon LaFraniere

articles.headline: Confidence Even as Hillary Clinton’s Momentum Slows
articles.snippet: Mrs. Clinton’s campaign was optimistic that she would weather the F.B.I.’s review of a top aide’s emails, but acknowledged that optimism of gaining ground in places like Ohio and Iowa was fading.
articles.abstract: Mrs. Clinton’s campaign was optimistic that she would weather the F.B.I.’s review of a top aide’s emails, but acknowledged that optimism of gaining ground in places like Ohio and Iowa was fading.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The announcement that the F.B.I. is reviewing newly discovered emails of a top Hillary Clinton aide has slowed the campaign’s momentum and the hopes of expanding support in traditional Midwestern battleground states. Leading Democratic strategists say the news has caused some of Mrs. Clinton’s more casual supporters to drift away.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: Why the Lone EpiPen Competitor Hasn’t Taken Off
articles.snippet: Adrenaclick, a cheaper alternative, has benefited from furor over EpiPen pricing. But its maker is struggling to meet demand, and a generic EpiPen is near.
articles.abstract: Adrenaclick, a cheaper alternative, has benefited from furor over EpiPen pricing. But its maker is struggling to meet demand, and a generic EpiPen is near.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the list price of a pair of EpiPen devices soared to more than $600 this summer, people scurried to find alternatives, occasionally throwing caution to the wind. Some bought cheap syringes filled with epinephrine, the medication in EpiPens; others made homemade auto-injectors, following the steps in a popular YouTube video.

articles.headline: Gannett Abandons Effort to Buy the Newspaper Publisher Tronc
articles.snippet: Investor expectations will now present tough questions for the former Tribune Publishing, owner of The Los Angeles Times and Chicago Tribune.
articles.abstract: Investor expectations will now present tough questions for the former Tribune Publishing, owner of The Los Angeles Times and Chicago Tribune.
articles.lead_paragraph: For a deal that took six months of battling back and forth, the message of its collapse was cursory.
articles.byline: By Leslie Picker and Sydney Ember

articles.headline: How Waning Competition Deepens Labor’s Plight
articles.snippet: As many markets become more concentrated, America’s competition policy can no longer be understood in the narrow terms of protecting consumers from higher prices.
articles.abstract: As many markets become more concentrated, America’s competition policy can no longer be understood in the narrow terms of protecting consumers from higher prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Communications Workers of America union has learned to appreciate corporate consolidation.

articles.headline: Assad in Person: Confident, Friendly, No Regrets
articles.snippet: Meeting reporters, Mr. Assad radiated confidence that he was firmly in control of his country, declaring that he planned to remain president until his term ends in 2021.
articles.abstract: Meeting reporters, Mr. Assad radiated confidence that he was firmly in control of his country, declaring that he planned to remain president until his term ends in 2021.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAMASCUS, Syria — The guns were silent atop Mount Qasioun and the lights on its slopes twinkled over Damascus as President Bashar al-Assad of Syria welcomed a group of Western visitors into his French-Ottoman palace on Monday night, presenting himself as a man firmly in control of his country.
